newsitem.title: UK: Aluminium price seen averaging $1,750 in 97 - Wolff.
newsitem.headline: Aluminium price seen averaging $1,750 in 97 - Wolff.

text.p: The aluminium market is expected to tighten further this year leading to a scramble for material that may send prices racing higher in a repeat of the 1993/95 bull run, broker Rudolf Wolff said.
Three month LME prices are expected to average $1,750 per tonne in 1997, Wolff said in a report.
"With the market strengthening and the funds beginning to establish long positions, a repeat of the 1993/95 bull run may emerge," Wolff said.
A slowdown in Western World economies after 1995 led to a prolonged period of destocking due to an excessive build up in inventories throughout 1993/95.
But now consumers are reluctant to build up stocks again in case the recovery peters out.
"Therefore, expect total commercial stocks to fall ever closer towards the critical six weeks level," Wolff added.
LME and total commerical stocks are 64 percent and 44 percent lower, respectively, than at their peaks in 1994.
Demand for the metal is expected to be seen buoyant in developing countries as their desire for improved infrastructure and Western goods increases.
Over the last decade, developing world demand for aluminium has risen by 110 percent or 3.3 million tonnes versus the developed world's growth of 23 percent.
Net exports from Eastern nations are seen falling by 150,000 tonnes to 2.25 million while most of the 1.2 million tonnes of idled capacity is unlikely to come on stream, Wolff said.
